clusters.title: Father of child killed in Minneapolis shooting speaks, "A coward decided to take our 8-year-old son"
clusters.neutral_headline: Father speaks after son killed in Minneapolis school shooting

items.title: Father of child killed in Minneapolis shooting speaks, "A coward decided to take our 8-year-old son"
items.standfirst: Jesse Merkel's son, Fletcher, was one of the two students killed in Wednesday's shooting at Annunciation Catholic Church in Minneapolis. He delivered a statement Thursday, saying in part, "Fletcher loved his family, friends, fishing, cooking and any sport that he was allowed to play."
items.content: Jesse Merkel's son, Fletcher, was one of the two students killed in Wednesday's shooting at Annunciation Catholic Church in Minneapolis. He delivered a statement Thursday, saying in part, "Fletcher loved his family, friends, fishing, cooking and any sport that he was allowed to play."

items.title: Minneapolis school attacker 'obsessed with idea of killing children', officials say
items.standfirst: The two children killed in the shooting have been identified as Fletcher Merkel, eight, and Harper Moyski, 10.
items.content: The two children killed in the shooting have been identified as Fletcher Merkel, eight, and Harper Moyski, 10.

items.title: Middle schoolers are lauded for protecting younger kids during church shooting

items.content: Two children were killed, and 18 children between the ages 6 and 15 were injured by a shooter. Middle schoolers acted heroically to protect others, a parent said.(Image credit: Stephen Maturen)

items.title: Minneapolis community mourns children after shooting, hopes for recoveries

items.content: Investigators are recovering more evidence and are searching for a motive in Wednesday's shooting at a Minneapolis catholic school that killed two children. CBS News' Lana Zak and Anna Schecter report.

items.title: 'Give your kids an extra hug and kiss': Father of 8-year-old victim speaks out
items.standfirst: Jesse Merkel, the father of 8-year-old Minneapolis shooting victim Fletcher Merkel, spoke out after the violent attack that killed his son. Merkel asked that his son be remembered for who he was, not the act of violence that ended his life.
items.content: Jesse Merkel, the father of 8-year-old Minneapolis shooting victim Fletcher Merkel, spoke out after the violent attack that killed his son. Merkel asked that his son be remembered for who he was, not the act of violence that ended his life.

items.title: Families of 2 killed in Minneapolis school shooting issue statements

items.content: The families of the two children who were shot and killed early Wednesday morning at Annunciation Catholic Church in southwest Minneapolis spoke out for the first time Thursday afternoon.

items.standfirst: Two children were killed and 18 other people were injured when the shooter opened fire at Annunciation Catholic Church during a Mass.
items.content: Two children were killed and 18 other people were injured when the shooter opened fire at Annunciation Catholic Church during a Mass.

items.content: New details on the investigation into the shooting at a Minneapolis Catholic school. Plus, a man describes hearing the gunshots and rushing to help.

items.title: Police combing through Minneapolis Catholic school shooter's writings in search of motive

items.content: Investigators are poring through the Minneapolis Catholic school shooter's writings in search of answers. CBS News correspondent Lana Zak reports. Then, Minnesota State Rep. Emma Greenman joins to discuss further.

items.title: Aaron Rupar, father of Annunciation Catholic School students, shares his story

items.content: Aaron Rupar is the father of two Annunciation Catholic School students. He joined CBS News to share his story about Thursday's shooting.

items.title: Minneapolis school shooting: police say locked doors saved ‘countless lives’
items.standfirst: Shooter tried to enter church to carry out attack but failed since doors had been locked when mass began, officials sayAs Minneapolis grappled with the aftermath of the mass shooting at a Catholic school church in which two children were killed and 17 people injured, police said “countless lives” had been saved by the church doors being locked as the shooter had not been able to get inside.Two children, aged eight and 10, were killed in the church pews during morning mass at the Annunciation Catholic school church. Fourteen other children, aged six to 15, were also injured, two of them critically, though officials said they were expected to survive. Three adults, parishioners in their 80s, were also injured. Police said the suspect, Robin Westman, 23, killed themself and was found dead behind the church. Continue reading...
items.content: Shooter tried to enter church to carry out attack but failed since doors had been locked when mass began, officials sayAs Minneapolis grappled with the aftermath of the mass shooting at a Catholic school church in which two children were killed and 17 people injured, police said “countless lives” had been saved by the church doors being locked as the shooter had not been able to get inside.Two children, aged eight and 10, were killed in the church pews during morning mass at the Annunciation Catholic school church. Fourteen other children, aged six to 15, were also injured, two of them critically, though officials said they were expected to survive. Three adults, parishioners in their 80s, were also injured. Police said the suspect, Robin Westman, 23, killed themself and was found dead behind the church. Continue reading...

items.content: Police have released new details about the killer in the US Catholic school shooting - including that they "idolised" mass murderers and they wanted to "watch children suffer".

The shooting occurred at Annunciation Catholic Church during a Mass, injuring 18 others.
Investigators are gathering evidence and seeking a motive for the Wednesday shooting.
Families of the victims issued statements, expressing grief and seeking support.

items.standfirst: US president spent months waging campaign against Fed’s leaders, which has raised questions over its independenceUS politics live – latest updatesThe Federal Reserve governor Lisa Cook has filed a lawsuit against Donald Trump over his “unprecedented and illegal attempt” to fire her, calling it an attempt to undermine the central bank’s independence.The lawsuit – filed by Cook in federal court in Washington on Thursday – sets the stage for a legal battle over the US president’s extraordinary push for greater control of the central bank. Continue reading...

items.title: White House reportedly picks Kennedy deputy to replace fired CDC chief
items.standfirst: Susan Monarez says only Trump can remove her as four other senior CDC leaders quit over political interferenceUS politics live – latest updatesWho’s who in the CDC crisis?The White House has reportedly chosen a deputy of Robert F Kennedy Jr to serve as the acting head of the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), a decision that comes as the standoff over the firing of director Susan Monarez, has deepened, with Monarez’s lawyers claiming she will not depart unless Donald Trump himself removes her.The Associated Press and the Washington Post reported on Thursday, citing sources familiar with the decision, that the White House has selected Jim O’Neill, currently the deputy secretary of the Department of Health and Human Services. The decision would give Kennedy a CDC chief who will be on board with his efforts to overhaul federal vaccine policy, the Post reported. Continue reading...
items.content: Susan Monarez says only Trump can remove her as four other senior CDC leaders quit over political interferenceUS politics live – latest updatesWho’s who in the CDC crisis?The White House has reportedly chosen a deputy of Robert F Kennedy Jr to serve as the acting head of the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), a decision that comes as the standoff over the firing of director Susan Monarez, has deepened, with Monarez’s lawyers claiming she will not depart unless Donald Trump himself removes her.The Associated Press and the Washington Post reported on Thursday, citing sources familiar with the decision, that the White House has selected Jim O’Neill, currently the deputy secretary of the Department of Health and Human Services. The decision would give Kennedy a CDC chief who will be on board with his efforts to overhaul federal vaccine policy, the Post reported. Continue reading...

clusters.title: Why France, Germany, and the UK want to reimpose sanctions on Iran
clusters.neutral_headline: UK, France, Germany plan to reimpose sanctions on Iran

items.title: Why France, Germany, and the UK want to reimpose sanctions on Iran
items.standfirst: France, Germany, and the UK are starting a 30-day process to reimpose sanctions on Iran over its nuclear programme.
items.content: France, Germany, and the UK are starting a 30-day process to reimpose sanctions on Iran over its nuclear programme.

items.title: Iran says sanctions snapback to 'undermine' cooperation with UN nuclear watchdog
items.standfirst: Iran said Thursday the decision by European powers to trigger a mechanism reimposing sanctions under a moribund 2015 nuclear deal would undermine Tehran's cooperation with the United Nations nuclear watchdog. FRANCE 24's Saeed Azimi reports from Tehran.
items.content: Iran said Thursday the decision by European powers to trigger a mechanism reimposing sanctions under a moribund 2015 nuclear deal would undermine Tehran's cooperation with the United Nations nuclear watchdog. FRANCE 24's Saeed Azimi reports from Tehran.

items.title: Iran faces a return of U.N. sanctions — what happens now?
items.standfirst: Britain, France and Germany launched a 30-day process to reimpose U.N. sanctions on Iran over its nuclear programme on Thursday, according to a letter sent by the three nations to the U.N.
items.content: Britain, France and Germany launched a 30-day process to reimpose U.N. sanctions on Iran over its nuclear programme on Thursday, according to a letter sent by the three nations to the U.N.

items.title: UK, France and Germany move to reimpose UN sanctions on Iran
items.standfirst: The three powers trigger a process which could restore sanctions in 30 days, calling Iran's nuclear programme a threat to peace and security.
items.content: The three powers trigger a process which could restore sanctions in 30 days, calling Iran's nuclear programme a threat to peace and security.

items.title: UK, France and Germany plan to reimpose sanctions on Iran over nuclear weapon fears
items.standfirst: The UK, France and Germany are planning to revive UN-backed sanctions on Iran over fears it is developing nuclear weapons.
items.content: The UK, France and Germany are planning to revive UN-backed sanctions on Iran over fears it is developing nuclear weapons.

items.title: Iran warns return of sanctions will ‘seriously undermine’ cooperation with UN nuclear watchdog
items.standfirst: Iran said the decision by Britain, France and Germany to launch a 30-day process to reimpose UN sanctions over its nuclear programme was a “provocative and unnecessary escalation” that would undermine the ongoing process of cooperation between Iran and the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA).
items.content: Iran said the decision by Britain, France and Germany to launch a 30-day process to reimpose UN sanctions over its nuclear programme was a “provocative and unnecessary escalation” that would undermine the ongoing process of cooperation between Iran and the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA).

ai_summary: The UK, France, and Germany initiated a process to reimpose UN sanctions on Iran.
The move is related to concerns about Iran's nuclear program.
Iran stated the sanctions would undermine cooperation with the UN nuclear watchdog.
The European powers are starting a 30-day process to reimpose sanctions.
Iran called the decision a "provocative and unnecessary escalation."

items.title: Putin and Kim to join Xi at Chinese military parade in show of defiance to the west
items.standfirst: The Victory Day parade in Beijing on 3 September will mark the formal surrender of Japan during the second world war. No western leaders will attendVladimir Putin and Kim Jong-un are among the world leaders who will attend a military parade with President Xi Jinping in Beijing next week, in a show of collective defiance amid western pressure.No western leaders will be among the 26 foreign heads of state and government attending the parade next week – with the exception of Robert Fico, prime minister of Slovakia, a member of the European Union – according to the Chinese foreign ministry. Continue reading...

No western leaders will attendVladimir Putin and Kim Jong-un are among the world leaders who will attend a military parade with President Xi Jinping in Beijing next week, in a show of collective defiance amid western pressure.No western leaders will be among the 26 foreign heads of state and government attending the parade next week – with the exception of Robert Fico, prime minister of Slovakia, a member of the European Union – according to the Chinese foreign ministry. items.content: Kim Jong Un will join Xi Jinping and Vladimir Putin at a major military parade in Beijing next week, North Korean and Chinese state media have announced.

items.content: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un will make a rare international visit next week to attend a military parade in the Chinese capital, Chinese state media reported Thursday.

ai_summary: Kim Jong Un and Vladimir Putin will attend a military parade in China.
The parade is a show of defiance against Western pressure.
The event will take place in Beijing next week.
No Western leaders will attend the parade.
The parade marks the formal surrender of Japan during World War II.

clusters.title: "Alligator Alcatraz" could soon be empty, email suggests

items.title: "Alligator Alcatraz" could soon be empty, email suggests

items.content: An email obtained by CBS News from a Florida Division of Emergency Management director states "Alligator Alcatraz" could go "down to zero individuals within a few days." CBS News immigration and politics reporter Camilo Montoya-Galvez has the details.

items.content: Officials confirm that the Florida facility may soon be empty following a court ruling to shutter the complex.

items.title: Florida's 'Alligator Alcatraz' detention facility to be empty 'within a few days'

items.content: The immigration detention center in Florida's Everglades will soon be empty. State officials expect the facility to have no detainees "within a few days."(Image credit: Andrew Caballero-Reynolds)

ai_summary: An email suggests the Florida detention facility, "Alligator Alcatraz," may empty soon.

The emptying of the facility follows a court ruling.

clusters.title: BBC reports from scene of deadly Russian attack on Kyiv
clusters.neutral_headline: Deadly Russian attack on Kyiv kills at least 15

items.title: BBC reports from scene of deadly Russian attack on Kyiv
items.standfirst: Russia launched a major attack on Ukraine's capital in the early hours of Thursday evening, killing at least 19 people, including four children.
items.content: Russia launched a major attack on Ukraine's capital in the early hours of Thursday evening, killing at least 19 people, including four children.

items.title: Deadly Russian attack kills 21 in Kyiv
items.standfirst: Russian missiles and drones ripped through apartment blocks in the Ukrainian capital Kyiv early Thursday, killing at least 21 people, including four children, an attack that President Volodymyr Zelensky said showed Moscow's rejection of peace negotiations. FRANCE 24's Emmanuelle Chaze reports from Kyiv.
items.content: Russian missiles and drones ripped through apartment blocks in the Ukrainian capital Kyiv early Thursday, killing at least 21 people, including four children, an attack that President Volodymyr Zelensky said showed Moscow's rejection of peace negotiations. FRANCE 24's Emmanuelle Chaze reports from Kyiv.

items.title: Deadly Russian strike hits central Kyiv
items.standfirst: A “massive” Russian assault on Kyiv early Thursday resulted in the deaths of at least 12 people and left dozens more injured, according to Ukrainian officials. items.title: UN Security Council votes to end peacekeeping force in Lebanon after 2026
items.standfirst: Bowing to US and Israeli demands, the UN Security Council voted unanimously on Thursday to terminate the multinational peacekeeping force in southern Lebanon. The resolution gives the force, known as UNIFIL, a year starting on Dec. 31, 2026, to withdraw its 10,800 military and civilian personnel and all UN equipment.
items.content: Bowing to US and Israeli demands, the UN Security Council voted unanimously on Thursday to terminate the multinational peacekeeping force in southern Lebanon. The resolution gives the force, known as UNIFIL, a year starting on Dec. 31, 2026, to withdraw its 10,800 military and civilian personnel and all UN equipment.
